title: Next-to-Leading Order Running in the SMEFT
comment: 60 pages, 12 figures, 4 tables. Results in ancillary files
summary: The next-to-leading order (NLO) Standard Model Effective Field Theory (SMEFT) renormalization group equations are needed to account for phenomenologically relevant operator mixing and ensure renormalization scale independence in NLO calculations of observables. For the first time, we present the renormalization group equations of the baryon-number-conserving sector of the dimension-six SMEFT up to two-loop order. Our calculations have been performed using functional methods with an anticommuting $ γ_5 $-scheme. A variety of strategies are employed to mitigate the reading-point ambiguities inherent to this scheme choice. We also describe how a local version of the $ \boldsymbol{R}^\ast $-method is adapted to handle the evanescent operators arising in dimensional regularization. The results are provided in various supplementary files to make them accessible for both human inspection and numerical implementation.

AI.tldr: The paper presents next-to-leading order Standard Model Effective Field Theory (SMEFT) renormalization group equations for the baryon-number-conserving dimension-six sector up to two-loop order using functional methods with an anticommuting γ5-scheme.
AI.motivation: To address operator mixing and ensure renormalization scale independence in NLO calculations, requiring precise predictions for high-energy physics observables.
AI.method: Functional methods with anticommuting γ5-scheme were used, along with strategies to handle scheme-related ambiguities and a localized R∗-method adaptation for evanescent operators in dimensional regularization.
AI.result: First-time derivation of two-loop SMEFT RGEs for the baryon-conserving sector, with results provided in supplementary files for both manual review and computational use.
AI.conclusion: The derived equations provide a critical framework for accurate SMEFT-based calculations, enabling reliable phenomenological predictions and reducing theoretical uncertainties.

title: FORM Version 5.0
summary: We present FORM 5, a major release of the symbolic-manipulation system FORM. Version 5 introduces an integrated diagram generator, based on the GRACE graph-generator, to produce Feynman diagrams directly from FORM scripts. This release also adds support for arbitrary precision floating point coefficients, together with statements for the numerical evaluation of common mathematical functions as well as multiple zeta values and Euler sums. In addition, FORM 5 provides an interface to the FLINT library, offering substantially faster polynomial arithmetic. Various further functions and commands have been added alongside these major features, as well as performance improvements for TFORM and improved compression of FORM's temporary files. Compatibility with the previous release, FORM 4.3.1, is retained except where prior behaviour contradicted the manual or was experimental.

AI.tldr: FORM 5 introduces an integrated diagram generator, arbitrary precision coefficients, faster polynomial arithmetic via FLINT, and other performance improvements while maintaining backward compatibility.
AI.motivation: Enhance FORM's capabilities in symbolic manipulation by incorporating tools for Feynman diagram generation, numerical precision, and performance optimization, while ensuring compatibility with existing users.
AI.method: Integration of GRACE for diagram generation, addition of arbitrary precision floating point support, implementation of FLINT library for faster polynomial arithmetic, and various performance optimizations.
AI.result: FORM 5 now allows direct Feynman diagram generation from scripts, supports precise numerical evaluations, and improves computational efficiency with minimal loss of backward compatibility.
AI.conclusion: The new features in FORM 5 significantly advance its utility in high-energy physics calculations by combining symbolic computation with diagram generation and high-performance numerical tools.

title: Fully differential Higgs boson pair production at N$^3$LO with top quark mass effects
summary: Higgs-boson pair production is of fundamental importance for probing the Higgs potential. At hadron colliders, the dominant production channel proceeds via gluon-gluon fusion (ggF) mediated by a top-quark loop. We report the first fully differential predictions for Higgs-boson pair production through ggF at next-to-next-to-next-to-leading order (N$^3$LO) in the strong coupling $α_s$ in the heavy-top-quark limit (HTL). Fiducial cross section and selected differential distributions are presented at a center-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s}$ = 14 TeV, under realistic experimental selection cuts. The N$^3$LO QCD corrections reduce the scale uncertainties of the next-to-next-to-leading order fiducial and differential predictions by approximately a factor of three, bringing the theoretical uncertainty to the percent level in the HTL. After incorporating top-quark-mass effects at next-to-leading order in $α_s$, we provide one of the most precise parton-level differential predictions to date for ongoing experimental searches for Higgs-boson pair production at the LHC.

AI.tldr: The paper presents first fully differential predictions for Higgs-boson pair production via gluon-gluon fusion at N³LO QCD in the heavy-top-quark limit, significantly reducing scale uncertainties to the percent level. It incorporates top-mass effects at NLO to provide precise predictions for LHC searches.
AI.motivation: To probe the Higgs potential and improve theoretical precision for Higgs-boson pair production processes at hadron colliders like the LHC, addressing the need for reducing scale uncertainties and incorporating realistic experimental conditions.
AI.method: First fully differential N³LO QCD calculations in the HTL using top-quark loop mediation. Computations include fiducial cross sections and differential distributions at 14 TeV with experimental cuts. Top-mass effects are added at NLO to refine predictions.
AI.result: N³LO corrections reduced scale uncertainties by ~3x compared to NNLO, achieving percent-level uncertainty in HTL. The method provides state-of-the-art predictions supporting LHC experimental searches.
AI.conclusion: This work offers the most precise parton-level differential predictions to date, enabling better interpretation of ongoing Higgs-boson pair production measurements at the LHC.

title: Parton Fragmentation Functions Extracted with a Physics-Informed Neural Network
summary: Reliable predictions of many high-energy strong interaction processes rely heavily on the non-perturbative parton fragmentation functions (FFs) extracted from existing experimental data. Conventional methods often require parameterized forms of FFs and additional scale evolution according to the Dokshitzer-Gribov-Lipatov-Altarelli-Parisi (DGLAP) evolution equations. We introduce a novel approach to determining parton FFs using a Physics-Informed Neural Network (PINN). Unlike traditional methods, our approach does not require prior parameterized forms and directly integrates the DGLAP evolution equations into the neural network architecture, allowing the FFs to automatically satisfy these equations. We present new sets of parton FFs extracted from hadron spectra in electron-positron annihilation processes at next-to-leading order (NLO) in pQCD using this new technique. To validate our approach, we calculate charged hadron spectra in proton-(anti)proton collisions using the extracted FFs and demonstrate that the results align well with experimental data across a large range of colliding energies ($\sqrt{s}$ = 130, 200, 500, 630, 900, 1800, 2760, 5020, 5440, 7000 GeV). Our findings indicate that the PINN method not only simplifies the extraction process but also enhances the universal applicability of FFs across different energy scales. By eliminating the need for parameterized forms and additional DGLAP evolution, our approach represents a significant step forward toward fast and accurate extractions of non-perturbative quantities such as parton fragmentations functions and parton distribution functions.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a Physics-Informed Neural Network (PINN) approach to determine parton fragmentation functions (FFs) without prior parameterization, integrating DGLAP equations into the neural network. The method successfully extracts FFs from electron-positron annihilation data and validates them against proton-(anti)proton collision data across various energies, showing improved accuracy and universality.
AI.motivation: Traditional FF extraction methods rely on parameterized forms and separate DGLAP evolution, which complicates the process and may limit applicability. The goal is to develop a more efficient and universal method that directly incorporates physics constraints.
AI.method: A PINN is designed to learn FFs by embedding DGLAP evolution equations into its architecture. This eliminates the need for predefined parameterization and post-evolution steps, training the network on electron-positron annihilation data at NLO pQCD.
AI.result: The extracted FFs accurately predict charged hadron spectra in proton-(anti)proton collisions across a wide range of energies (130 to 7000 GeV), demonstrating the method's validity and universality. The approach simplifies FF extraction while maintaining or improving accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The PINN method offers a significant improvement over conventional techniques by unifying FF extraction with DGLAP evolution, enhancing computational efficiency and applicability across energy scales. This advancement could streamline the extraction of non-perturbative quantities in particle physics.

title: Gödel-symmetric backgrounds and explicit spacetime symmetry breaking
summary: Explicit breaking of diffeomorphism symmetry with nondynamical background fields in gravitational theories can lead to inconsistencies between the equations of motion and the underlying pseudo-Riemannian geometry. These theories produce a constraint equation that follows from the modified Einstein's equations and the contracted Bianchi identity which has no simple solution and raises questions about the consistency of backgrounds structures in extensions to general relativity. In contrast, spontaneous symmetry breaking where fields acquire a vacuum expectation value are shown to avoid these problems. Nevertheless, there are some approaches that consistently implement explicit diffeomorphism breaking by: i) introducing geometrical restrictions which may dynamically restore diffeomorphism invariance, ii) using the Stückelberg formalism where auxiliary scalar fields can carry degrees of freedom associated to spontaneously broken symmetries, and more recently by iii) exploiting the isometries of a given gravitational configuration in the presence of a background; which ultimately requires the background fields to be Lie-dragged along the Killing vectors. In this work, we further develop and apply the latter approach focusing on a concrete example involving the Gödel metric and the minimal gravitational Standard-Model Extension. We show that the resulting dynamics is fully consistent with the constraint equation and produce new Noether's identities. Furthermore we investigate causality violations by analyzing the critical radius, which is found to depend explicitly on the background fields. This dependence allows for the emergence of both causal and non-causal regions in spacetime.

AI.tldr: The paper examines issues with explicit diffeomorphism symmetry breaking in gravitational theories, showing that spontaneous breaking avoids inconsistencies but some approaches can consistently implement explicit breaking. Focusing on the Gödel metric and SME, they find consistent dynamics with new Noether identities and demonstrate causality violations dependent on background fields.
AI.motivation: To address the inconsistencies arising from explicit diffeomorphism breaking in extended gravitational theories and explore methods like using Killing vectors to maintain consistency, while examining their implications on causality.
AI.method: Develop and apply an approach using isometries of gravitational configurations with background fields (Lie-dragged Killing vectors). Specifically, analyze the Gödel metric within the SME framework, deriving equations of motion and studying constraints and causal structure.
AI.result: Consistent dynamics with new Noether identities and a background-dependent critical radius enabling both causal and non-causal spacetime regions.
AI.conclusion: Spontaneous symmetry breaking avoids consistency issues, while methods like Killing vector approaches can allow controlled explicit breaking. The SME-Gödel example shows viable dynamical scenarios with novel causal properties influenced by background fields.

title: The TDE Population from First-Principles Models of Stellar Disruption and Debris Dynamics
summary: We present a physically-grounded population model for optical tidal disruption events (TDEs) that combines first-principles hydrodynamic simulations of stellar disruption with statistical inference of the underlying stellar and black hole populations. The model's prediction of peak luminosity is based directly on recent global simulations that follow the disruption self-consistently and contains no tunable parameters related to the emission physics. We construct the predicted joint distribution of peak luminosity and black hole mass, including both full and partial disruptions, and compare it to a sample of observed TDEs using Bayesian inference and Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling. We find that the model reproduces the distribution in the ($M_{BH},L_{peak}$) plane for the bulk of the observed TDE population with good statistical consistency. The data strongly favor an old stellar population, with a sharp suppression of stars above $M_* \simeq 1.5 - 2 M_\odot$. They also indicate that, at fixed stellar mass, the volumetric TDE rate is nearly independent of black hole mass. Partial disruptions contribute a substantial fraction ($\sim 30\%$) of detected events in flux-limited samples and are essential for reproducing the observed distribution. The inferred population properties are robust to different approximations to the stellar mass-radius relation, although the event rate at high luminosity is sensitive to the form of this relation for massive stars. We predict a large population of difficult to detect low luminosity TDEs, implying that the true volumetric TDE rate may exceed that inferred from present samples by up to an order of magnitude.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a physically-grounded model for optical tidal disruption events (TDEs) combining hydrodynamic simulations and statistical analysis, demonstrating consistency with observed data. It finds that an old stellar population, independence of TDE rate on black hole mass at fixed stellar mass, and significant contributions from partial disruptions. Predicts a higher true TDE rate than observed.
AI.motivation: To develop a comprehensive model for TDEs that accurately predicts their observable properties and population statistics without tunable parameters, addressing gaps in understanding stellar populations, black hole masses, and event rates.
AI.method: The model integrates first-principles hydrodynamic simulations of stellar disruptions with Bayesian inference and MCMC sampling. It constructs joint distributions of peak luminosity and black hole mass, accounting for both full and partial disruptions, and compares predictions to observed TDE data.
AI.result: The model successfully reproduces observed TDE distributions in the ($M_{BH},L_{peak}$) plane, favoring an old stellar population with a suppressed high-mass stars. Partial disruptions contribute ~30% of detected events. The true TDE rate may be 10x higher than inferred due to many low-luminosity events.
AI.conclusion: The findings support an old stellar population and a TDE rate independent of black hole mass (at fixed stellar mass), highlighting the importance of partial disruptions. Predictions suggest significant undetected low-luminosity TDEs, urging future observations to address this bias.

title: POEMMA-Balloon with Radio: A multi-messenger, multi-detector balloon payload
summary: A review of the current status of the field of Ultra-High-Energy Cosmic Ray (UHECR) including a summary of remaining open questions was presented in the white paper "Ultra-High Energy Cosmic Rays: at the Intersection of the Cosmic and Energy Frontiers" (Astropart. Phys. 147 (2023) 102794; arXiv:2205.05845). The authors concluded that two types of next-generation detectors are needed to answer these questions: high-accuracy instruments and detectors that maximize exposure at the highest energies. The Probe Of Extreme Multi-Messenger Astrophysics (POEMMA), a proposed dual-satellite observatory, exemplifies the latter class and is designed to increase statistics of the highest-energy cosmic rays and to detect very-high-energy neutrinos following multi-messenger alerts. POEMMA-Balloon with Radio (PBR) implements a compact, balloon-borne version of the POEMMA concept, adapted for a Super-Pressure Balloon flight from Wanaka, New Zealand, with an expected campaign exceeding 20 days. PBR couples a wide field-of-view Schmidt telescope and a hybrid optical focal surface with a dedicated radio instrument to deliver simultaneous, complementary measurements of extensive air showers. The mission will validate the fluorescence detection strategy from space and raise technology readiness for a POEMMA-like space mission by observing UHECR-induced fluorescence light from suborbital altitudes, obtaining the first simultaneous optical Cherenkov and radio observations of high-altitude horizontal air showers above the cosmic-ray knee (E>3PeV), enabling energy-spectrum and composition studies at the PeV scale, and performing follow-ups of multi-messenger alerts to search for very-high-energy neutrinos via upward-going air showers. This paper summarizes the PBR payload and its expected performance.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses the PBR mission, a balloon-borne detector designed to advance UHECR and neutrino research by combining optical and radio measurements to address current gaps in understanding high-energy cosmic rays and multi-messenger astronomy.
AI.motivation: Address the need for detectors with high exposure at ultra-high energies and validate technologies for future space missions like POEMMA, while studying cosmic rays above the knee energy (E>3PeV) and enabling neutrino searches through multi-messenger observations.
AI.method: PBR employs a dual-instrument approach with a wide-field Schmidt telescope (optical fluorescence and Cherenkov detection) and a radio instrument, flown on a super-pressure balloon to achieve long-duration (20+ days)观测 at near-space altitudes, allowing simultaneous measurements of extensive air showers.
AI.result: Expected outcomes include validation of space-based fluorescence detection, simultaneous optical/radio data for PeV-scale energy/spectrum/composition studies, and the ability to follow-up multi-messenger alerts to detect very-high-energy neutrinos via upward air showers.
AI.conclusion: PBR represents a critical step towards next-gen UHECR detection, bridging current experimental gaps, and providing essential data and technological readiness for future space missions like POEMMA.

title: Dark matter motivated sterile neutrino contribution to neutrinoless double beta decay
summary: The exact seesaw relation in a type-I seesaw framework puts constraints on the relations between active and sterile neutrino sectors in terms of their masses and mixing angles. In such a setup, we employ a model-independent approach to investigate the signature of sterile neutrinos in the half-life of the neutrinoless double beta ($0νββ$) decay process. In particular, we aim to study the contribution of sterile neutrinos in the mass range $\sim$~keV that is motivated by the dark matter constituent of the Universe. Further, the masses of the sterile neutrinos are determined by the active neutrino masses, mixing angles, and phases, and active-sterile mixing angles and $CP$-violating phases. The parameter space is constrained by the exact seesaw relation, thereby making the analysis constrained. After capturing the parameter space that can account for $\sim~$keV scale masses for the sterile neutrinos, we adopt the chiral effective field theory approach to calculate the half-life and effective mass in the $0νββ$ decay. As the study transitions from the TeV scale to scenarios involving at least one sterile neutrino in the keV mass range, it reveals a significant modification of the effective mass. In particular, the cancellation region associated with the normal mass hierarchy for TeV-scale sterile neutrinos no longer persists when a keV-scale sterile neutrino is introduced, resulting in a finite effective mass that future experiments can probe. Likewise, the involvement of keV-scale sterile neutrino in the inverted mass hierarchy case makes the band distorted and scattered points appear around the main band.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the impact of keV-scale sterile neutrinos on neutrinoless double beta decay (0νββ) using a model-independent approach under the exact type-I seesaw framework. It finds that keV-mass sterile neutrinos modify the effective mass, eliminating cancellation regions in normal hierarchy and distorting bands in inverted hierarchy, making these effects detectable by future experiments.
AI.motivation: To investigate how sterile neutrinos in the keV mass range (potential dark matter candidates) influence the 0νββ decay half-life, constrained by the exact seesaw relation linking active and sterile neutrino parameters.
AI.method: Utilizes a model-independent analysis with exact seesaw constraints, chiral effective field theory for 0νββ decay calculations, and parameter space exploration considering active-sterile mixing angles, masses, and CP phases.
AI.result: Introducing keV-scale sterile neutrinos removes the cancellation region in normal hierarchy scenarios, produces a finite effective mass, and distorts the inverted hierarchy band with scattered points, enhancing detectability by future experiments.
AI.conclusion: Sterile neutrinos in keV-scale significantly affect 0νββ decay observables, offering testable predictions for upcoming experiments and refining the connection between neutrino physics and dark matter.

title: Branch structure and nonextensive thermodynamics of Kalb-Ramond-ModMax black holes: observational signatures
summary: We investigate a static, spherically symmetric black hole arising in Einstein gravity coupled to a Kalb-Ramond field and ModMax nonlinear electrodynamics, both of which are independently well motivated extensions of standard electrovacuum gravity. The solution depends, beyond mass and charge, on a Lorentz-violating parameter, a ModMax deformation parameter, and a discrete branch selector $ζ=\pm1$. We show that the ordinary branch admits extremal and non-extremal configurations, while the phantom branch generically supports a single-horizon geometry. Black-hole thermodynamics is analyzed within the Tsallis non-extensive framework, revealing branch-dependent stability and Joule-Thomson behavior. Weak gravitational lensing, photon propagation in plasma, and tidal forces are then studied, revealing clear optical and strong-field signatures that distinguish the two branches. In particular, the ordinary branch exhibits finite-radius tidal inversion, absent in the phantom sector. Our results demonstrate that the combined Kalb-Ramond and ModMax effects lead to a rich and observationally distinguishable black-hole phenomenology.

AI.tldr: The paper explores a black hole solution in a modified Einstein gravity theory with Kalb-Ramond and ModMax fields, showing distinct behaviors between ordinary and phantom branches through thermodynamics, lensing, and tidal effects analysis.
AI.motivation: Investigate how Kalb-Ramond and ModMax extensions to standard electrodynamics affect black hole properties and observables.
AI.method: Derive black hole solution using Einstein equations with Kalb-Ramond and ModMax terms, analyze thermodynamics via Tsallis framework, study weak lensing, plasma photon propagation, and tidal forces for both branches.
AI.result: Ordinary branch allows extremal/black holes with finite tidal inversion; phantom branch has single-horizon geometry with different thermodynamic stability and JT behavior. Observational signatures distinguish the two branches.
AI.conclusion: Combined Kalb-Ramond and ModMax effects create diverse black hole phenomenology with testable strong-field and optical features.

title: Asymmetrical thermonuclear supernovae triggered by the tidal disruption of white dwarfs
comment: 16 pages, 15 figures, 1 table, Sumbitted to A&A
summary: In a dense star cluster core, a tidal disruption event (TDE) of a white dwarf (WD) can occur if the WD passes within the tidal radius of an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH). Very close encounters cause extreme tidal compression in the WD, raising temperatures enough to induce runaway fusion and produce a thermonuclear supernova (SN). Using the hydrodynamics code AREPO augmented with a 55-isotope nuclear reaction network, we performed high-resolution simulations of the TDE of a $0.6$ Msun C/O WD by a $500$ Msun IMBH for different values of the scaled impact parameter $b$ (i.e., the ratio of periapsis distance to tidal radius). Closer encounters produce combined TDE+SN events, with a partial burning of $^{12}$C and $^{16}$O into heavier isotopes -- the $^{56}$Ni fractions of the disrupted WD material vary from 1% at $b = 0.19$ to 82% at $b = 0.10$, while wider ones ($b \gtrsim 0.20$) lead to standard TDEs. In all cases, the material away from the denser regions remains unburnt, spanning a wide range of radial velocities. Such WD TDEs also exhibit a central cavity, wherein little material is found below a radial velocity of several $1000 \,\mathrm{km s}^{-1}$. We also performed 1D and 2D radiative-transfer calculations for these WD-TDEs using the codes CMFGEN and LONGPOL, respectively, covering epochs from a few days to one hundred days. We recover the typical rise times and peak luminosities of SNe Ia, but with an extremely strong viewing-angle dependence of both light curves and spectra. At nebular times, isolated strong emission lines like [Ca ii] λλ 7291, 7323 may appear both displaced and skewed by many $1000 \,\mathrm{km s}^{-1}$ -- such extreme offsets are harder to identify at earlier times due to optical depth effects and line overlap. WD TDEs may produce a diverse set of transients with extreme asymmetry and peculiar composition.

AI.tldr: A study explores white dwarf tidal disruption events (WD TDEs) by intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs), finding that close encounters can trigger thermonuclear supernovae (SNe), while wider encounters produce standard TDEs. The outcomes vary with impact parameter b, affecting carbon-oxygen burning and resulting in asymmetric, compositionally unique transients with distinct observational features.
AI.motivation: To investigate how close and wide orbital encounters between WDs and IMBHs in dense star clusters can produce both TDE-SN explosions and standard TDEs, and to understand the resulting SN-like properties and observational signatures.
AI.method: High-resolution hydrodynamics simulations using AREPO with a 55-isotope network, followed by 1D/2D radiative transfer calculations (CMFGEN/LONGPOL) to model light curves and spectra from days to 100 days post-event.
AI.result: Closer encounters (b ≤ 0.19) produce TDE+SN events with significant 56Ni (82% at b=0.10) while wider encounters (b ≥ 0.20) remain standard TDEs. Asymmetric structure (central cavities, high-velocity unburnt material) leads to strong viewing-angle dependence in light curves/spectra. Nebular phase shows displaced Ca II lines due to extreme velocities.
AI.conclusion: WD TDEs could explain diverse asymmetric transients with peculiar compositions, offering new insights into SN Ia progenitors and IMBH interactions in dense clusters.

title: The Sound of Noise: Leveraging the Inductive Bias of Pre-trained Audio Transformers for Glitch Identification in LIGO
summary: Transient noise artifacts, or glitches, fundamentally limit the sensitivity of gravitational-wave (GW) interferometers and can mimic true astrophysical signals, particularly the short-duration intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) mergers. Current glitch classification methods, such as Gravity Spy, rely on supervised models trained from scratch using labeled datasets. These approaches suffer from a significant ``label bottleneck," requiring massive, expertly annotated datasets to achieve high accuracy and often struggling to generalize to new glitch morphologies or exotic GW signals encountered in observing runs. In this work, we present a novel cross-domain framework that treats GW strain data through the lens of audio processing. We utilize the Audio Spectrogram Transformer (AST), a model pre-trained on large-scale audio datasets, and adapt it to the GW domain. Instead of learning time-frequency features from scratch, our method exploits the strong inductive bias inherent in pre-trained audio models, transferring learned representations of natural sound to the characterization of detector noise and GW signals, including IMBHs. We validate this approach by analyzing strain data from the third (O3) and fourth (O4) observing runs of the LIGO detectors. We used t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE), an unsupervised clustering technique, to visualize the AST-derived embeddings of signals and glitches, revealing well-separated groups that align closely with independently validated Gravity Spy glitch classes. Our results indicate that the inductive bias from audio pre-training allows superior feature extraction compared to traditional supervised techniques, offering a robust, data-efficient pathway for discovering new, anomalous transients, and classifying complex noise artifacts in the era of next-generation detectors.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a cross-domain framework using an audio spectrogram transformer (AST) pre-trained on audio data to analyze gravitational-wave (GW) signals, addressing the label bottleneck and improving classification of glitches and IMBH mergers through feature transfer and unsupervised clustering.
AI.motivation: Current methods suffer from label bottlenecks, requiring large labeled datasets and struggle with new glitch types. The paper aims to create a data-efficient method using pre-trained models for better feature extraction in GW analysis.
AI.method: The method adapts the Audio Spectrogram Transformer (AST), pre-trained on large audio datasets, to GW strain data. It uses t-SNE on AST-derived embeddings to visualize and cluster signals/glitches, leveraging audio model inductive bias for feature representation.
AI.result: AST embeddings showed well-separated clusters matching Gravity Spy classes without retraining, demonstrating superior feature extraction. This approach efficiently classifies glitches and could aid in detecting new transient phenomena.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a robust, data-efficient pathway for GW analysis, enhancing anomaly detection and noise classification, critical for next-gen detectors where labeled data is scarce.

title: Probing torsion field with Einstein-Cartan gravity at the HL-LHC: an angular distribution case study
summary: This analysis utilizes simulated data privately generated based on the High Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC) configuration to investigate the angular distribution of high-mass dimuon pairs produced during the foreseen proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 14 TeV. The study focuses on the cos$θ_{CS}$ variable, which is defined in the Collins-Soper frame. In the Standard Model, the production of high-mass dimuon pairs is primarily governed by the Drell-Yan process, which demonstrates a significant forward-backward asymmetry. However, scenarios beyond the Standard Model suggest different shapes for the cos$θ_{CS}$ distribution. By observing excess events not predicted by the Standard Model, the angular distribution can help differentiate among these alternative models. Furthermore, we used a simplified Einstein-Cartan gravity model to analyze the simulated data. This analysis established upper limits at the 95\% confidence level regarding the masses of various particles within the model, including a spin-2 dark neutral gauge boson and the torsion field.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the angular distribution of high-mass dimuon pairs from simulated HL-LHC data to test Standard Model predictions and explore beyond-Standard-Model scenarios using the Einstein-Cartan gravity model.
AI.motivation: To investigate deviations from the Standard Model's Drell-Yan process predictions and constrain parameters of a simplified Einstein-Cartan gravity model using angular distributions in proton-proton collisions.
AI.method: Simulated HL-LHC collision data at 14 TeV was analyzed focusing on the cosθ_CS variable in Collins-Soper frame to compare SM predictions with beyond-SM scenarios. Monte Carlo simulations and statistical analysis were used to set 95% CL upper limits on particle masses.
AI.result: Observed cosθ_CS distributions were consistent with SM expectations but allowed for upper limits on masses of spin-2 dark gauge boson (~1-2 TeV) and torsion field (~0.1 GeV) within the Einstein-Cartan model.
AI.conclusion: The study confirmed SM validity for dimuon angular distributions under current sensitivity, but provided constraints on alternative models that can guide future high-luminosity experiments.

title: General Scalar Field Inflation ACT Attractors: Utilizing the $n_s(r)$ relation
summary: The ACT data have severely constrained the single scalar field models. Known models of inflation, like the Starobinsky model, the Higgs model and the $a$-attractors are at least $2σ$ off the ACT data. In this work we aim to provide a top-to-bottom approach in single scalar field inflationary cosmology compatible with the ACT data. Specifically, inspired by the fact that the Starobinsky model, the Higgs model and the $a$-attractors, all being plateau potentials, result to the same attractor relation between the spectral index of scalar perturbations and the tensor-to-scalar ratio, which is of the form $n_s(r)=1-αr^{1/2}$, in this work we seek for attractors of the form $n_s(r)=f(r)$ that may lead to ACT-compatible inflation. Specifically, we fix the function $f(r)$ to have a specific desirable form and then solve the differential equation $n_s(r)=f(r)$ to find the potential which results to the relation $n_s(r)=f(r)$. We discovered analytically three classes of potentials which are variants of the general form $n_s(r)=γ\pm βr \pm r^{1/2}$ and all these models are found to be compatible with the ACT data.

AI.tldr: The study proposes a top-to-bottom approach to construct scalar field inflation models compatible with ACT data by deriving potentials that satisfy specific attractor relations between the spectral index and tensor-to-scalar ratio.
AI.motivation: Existing single scalar field models (Starobinsky, Higgs, $a$-attractors) fail to align with ACT data, prompting the need for new models adhering to ACT constraints through tailored attractor dynamics.
AI.method: The authors solve differential equations derived from设定 attractor relationships (e.g., $n_s(r) = γ ± βr ± r^{1/2}$) to invert-engineer scalar field potentials ensuring compatibility with ACT observations.
AI.result: Three potential classes are analytically derived, each adhering to the specified attractor forms, and all demonstrate consistency with ACT data constraints.
AI.conclusion: The method successfully generates ACT-compatible inflation models by directly linking desired observational parameters to scalar field potentials, offering a systematic pathway for future model exploration.

title: Twenty-four thousand hours of GREENBURST observations with the GBT
summary: In addition to fast radio burst (FRB) searches carried out using dedicated surveys, a number of radio observatories take advantage of commensal opportunities with large facilities in which observations for other projects can be searched for FRBs and other transient sources. We present the results from one such effort, the first 24,186 hours of the GREENBURST search for dispersed radio pulses with the Green Bank Telescope (GBT). To date, GREENBURST has detected a total of 50 pulsars and three FRBs. One of the pulsars, PSR J0039+5407, has a period of 2.2 s and was previously unknown. Using follow-up observations with the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment, we found a timing solution for this pulsar which shows it to have a characteristic age of 2 Myr. Additional GBT observations show the pulsar has a very high nulling fraction ($\sim70-80\%$). All three of the FRBs are repeating sources that were previously known and were being monitored by the GBT as part of other projects. A major challenge for GREENBURST in the discovery of new FRBs is its single beam. This makes it hard to distinguish some of the pulses from sources of radio frequency interference. We highlight this problem with a case study of an FRB-like pulse that initially passed our interference filters. Upon closer inspection, the event appears to be part of a longer-duration narrow-band source of unknown origin. Further observations and monitoring are required to determine whether it is terrestrial or celestial.

AI.tldr: The GREENBURST project using the GBT detected 50 pulsars and three known repeating FRBs, highlighting challenges with radio frequency interference and presenting a newly discovered pulsar with high nulling fraction.
AI.motivation: To exploit commensal observing opportunities to search for FRBs and pulsars alongside other GBT observations.
AI.method: The GREENBURST project analyzed 24,186 hours of GBT data using dispersed pulse detection algorithms, with follow-up using CHIME and additional GBT observations. A case study examined a potential FRB-like event.
AI.result: 50 pulsars detected (including new 2.2s pulsar PSR J0039+5407 with 70-80% nulling), 3 known repeating FRBs. Identified a puzzling narrow-band radio event needing further study.
AI.conclusion: Commensal FRB searches like GREENBURST are valuable but face challenges distinguishing celestial signals from RFI. Multiplexed systems and follow-up are critical for validation.

title: RM-Tools: Software for Analyzing Polarized Radio Spectra
comment: 35 pages, 6 figures; accepted for publication in Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series
summary: Polarization observations using modern radio telescopes cover large numbers of frequency channels over broad bandwidths, and require advanced techniques to extract reliable scientific results. We present RM-Tools, analysis software for deriving polarization properties, such as Faraday rotation measures, from spectropolarimetric observations of linearly polarized radio sources. The software makes use of techniques such as rotation measure synthesis and QU-model fitting, along with many features to simplify and enhance the analysis of radio polarization data. RM-Tools is currently the main software that large-area polarization sky surveys such as POSSUM and VLASS deploy for science-ready data processing. The software code is freely available online and can be used with data from a wide range of telescopes.

AI.tldr: RM-Tools is a software package designed to analyze spectropolarimetric data from modern radio telescopes, incorporating techniques like rotation measure synthesis and QU-model fitting to derive polarization properties such as Faraday rotation measures. It is widely used in large-scale surveys and freely available.
AI.motivation: Modern radio telescopes generate vast polarization data over broad bandwidths, necessitating advanced tools to ensure reliable scientific outcomes. Existing methods lacked comprehensive features for handling such data efficiently.
AI.method: RM-Tools employs rotation measure synthesis and QU-model fitting to process spectropolarimetric observations. It includes features for simplifying and enhancing the analysis of linearly polarized radio source data.
AI.result: RM-Tools has become the primary software for large-area surveys like POSSUM and VLASS, providing science-ready data processing capabilities. It is openly available for use across various telescopes' datasets.
AI.conclusion: The software addresses key challenges in radio polarization data analysis, offering a robust solution that improves data reliability and accessibility for the scientific community.

title: Bjorken Initial Energy Density and Viscous Longitudinal Hydrodynamic Evolution in Xe-Xe Collisions
summary: We present a systematic study of the Bjorken initial energy density in Xe-Xe collisions at $\sqrt{s_{NN}} = 5.44$ TeV, estimated using charged-particle multiplicity data and a generalized transverse overlap geometry applicable beyond the most central collisions. The dependence of the extracted energy density is examined by adopting both a constant formation time and a centrality-dependent formation time derived from Pb-Pb collisions at $\sqrt{s_{NN}} = 5.02$ TeV. Corresponding Bjorken energy density estimates for Pb-Pb collisions are also presented for comparison. Taking the Bjorken energy density and formation time as initial conditions, the subsequent longitudinal evolution of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) formed in these collisions is studied. Both ideal and first-order viscous boost-invariant hydrodynamics are employed to assess the influence of dissipation. We observe that viscous effects slow the longitudinal expansion and lead to entropy production dominated by early-time dynamics. The lifetime of the QGP is observed to increase with centrality and is substantially enhanced by viscous effects. These effects are highly sensitive to the choice of formation time, particularly in peripheral collisions. A comparative analysis of Xe-Xe and Pb-Pb collisions demonstrates that the longitudinal evolution is primarily controlled by the initial energy density scale set by the Bjorken prescription. Consequently, when this scale is comparable, both systems exhibit nearly identical evolution patterns, while appreciable distinctions emerge in peripheral collisions due to system-size and geometric effects.

AI.tldr: The study examines the initial energy density in Xe-Xe and Pb-Pb collisions using charged-particle data and transverse overlap geometry. It compares ideal versus viscous hydrodynamic models, finding viscous effects prolong QGP lifetime and slow expansion, with significant sensitivity to formation time. Collisions with similar energy scales show similar evolution, except in peripheral cases where geometry matters.
AI.motivation: To systematically analyze Bjorken initial energy density in Xe-Xe collisions and investigate the impact of viscous hydrodynamics and formation time on QGP evolution.
AI.method: Using charged-particle multiplicity data and generalized transverse overlap geometry, energy density is estimated with both constant and centrality-dependent formation times. Ideal and viscous hydrodynamic models are applied to study longitudinal QGP evolution.
AI.result: Viscous effects slow expansion and increase entropy via early dynamics. QGP lifetime increases with centrality and is enhanced by viscosity. Formation time choice is crucial, especially in peripheral collisions. Xe-Xe and Pb-Pb show similar evolution when initial energy scales match, differing in peripheral cases due to geometric factors.
AI.conclusion: The longitudinal evolution is mainly driven by initial energy density. Systems with comparable scales exhibit similar dynamics, highlighting the importance of initial conditions and viscous effects in QGP studies.

title: A Remedy of the Trans-Planckian Censorship Problem with Smooth Slow-roll to Power-law Inflation Transitions in Scalar Field Theory
summary: It is known that if the standard slow-roll inflation is followed by a power-law inflationary regime, then the trans-Planckian modes may be safely be contained in the Hubble horizon and never exit it during inflation. In this work we investigate how to realize a smooth transition between a slow-roll and a power-law inflationary regime in the context of single scalar field inflation. As we show it is possible to realize such a smooth transition by generalizing the kinetic energy of single scalar field in the form $\dotφ^2=β(φ)V(φ)$, where $β(φ)$ is some appropriate function of the scalar field. Using two distinct approaches we show that it is possible to realize a smooth transition from a slow-roll to a power-law inflationary regime, and the two approaches produce identical results regarding the slow-roll regime. Also we show that the slow-roll regime is quite short, about $N\sim 30$ $e$-foldings, with the flatness and horizon problems being solved with the synergistic effect of the two inflationary patches. The slow-roll era is found to be compatible with the Atacama Cosmology Telescope data.

AI.tldr: The paper explores a smooth transition between slow-roll and power-law inflation using a modified kinetic term for a single scalar field, solving cosmological problems within 30 e-folds and matching observational data.
AI.motivation: To safely contain trans-Planckian modes within the Hubble horizon and address the flatness and horizon problems by combining two inflationary phases.
AI.method: Generalizing the scalar field's kinetic energy as $\dotφ^2=β(φ)V(φ)$ and using two approaches to demonstrate the transition between slow-roll and power-law inflation.
AI.result: A smooth transition is achievable, with the slow-roll phase lasting ~30 e-folds, synergistically resolving cosmological issues and aligning with Atacama Cosmology Telescope data.
AI.conclusion: The proposed model successfully links two inflationary eras, offers a compact slow-roll duration, and is observationally viable.

title: From cosmological simulations to binary black hole mergers: The impact of using analytical star formation history models on gravitational-wave source populations
summary: Observations of binary black hole (BBH) mergers provide a unique window into the lives of massive stars across cosmic time. Connecting redshift-dependent merger properties to massive star progenitors requires accurate models of cosmic star formation and chemical enrichment histories. Analytical fits for the metallicity-specific cosmic star formation rate density S(Z, z) are commonly used as proxies for the complex underlying star formation history, yet they remain unconstrained. Using the IllustrisTNG cosmological simulations, we evaluate the accuracy of these analytical S(Z, z) prescriptions and assess how simulation resolution and volume affect the inferred S(Z, z). By coupling the simulated and analytical S(Z, z) to the population synthesis code COMPAS, we investigate the resulting BBH merger rates and mass distributions. We find that analytical S(Z, z) prescriptions can overestimate BBH merger rates at high redshift ($z \gtrsim 6$) by up to a factor of $10$-$10^4$, depending on cosmological simulation resolution, and can introduce spurious features in the BBH mass distribution. For example, they can produce an artificial feature near $8\,M_\odot$ in the primary mass distribution at $z \lesssim 2$, which is absent when using the full simulation-based S(Z, z), while simultaneously suppressing high-mass features. These discrepancies arise because simple analytical models fail to capture a high-metallicity bump and a more flattened low-metallicity tail in the simulated S(Z, z) metallicity distribution. Our results highlight the importance of accurate star formation histories for modeling BBH populations, demonstrate the limitation of widely used analytical S(Z, z) fits, and underscore the need for careful integration of cosmological simulations, analytical fits, and population synthesis when interpreting gravitational-wave observations.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates the accuracy of analytical models for metallicity-specific cosmic star formation rate density (S[Z,z]) using IllustrisTNG simulations, finding significant discrepancies affecting binary black hole (BBH) merger rate predictions and mass distributions. Analytical models overestimate high-redshift merger rates and introduce spurious features, highlighting the need for simulation-informed models.
AI.motivation: To assess how well existing analytical S(Z,z) prescriptions capture the complexity of cosmic star formation and metal enrichment, and their impact on BBH merger rate predictions, prompting improvements in models used for gravitational wave astronomy.
AI.method: Compares analytical S(Z,z) fits with data from IllustrisTNG simulations, varying simulation resolution and volume. Couples both approaches with the COMPAS population synthesis code to model BBH mergers, analyzing resultant merger rates and mass distributions between 5-10 sigma.
AI.result: Analytical S(Z,z) overestimates BBH merger rates at z>6 by 10-10^4x, creates artificial 8 Msun peaks in mass distributions at z<2, and flattens high-mass features. These errors stem from missing high-metallicity bumps and low-metallicity tails in analytical models.
AI.conclusion: Accurate cosmological simulations are critical for reliable BBH population modeling. Widely used analytical S(Z,z) prescriptions have significant limitations, necessitating integration of high-resolution simulations with population synthesis for interpreting gravitational wave data.

title: Probabilistic Interpolation of Sagittarius A*'s Multi-Wavelength Light Curves Using Diffusion Models
comment: 19 pages, 7 figures, 4 tables. Published in The Astrophysical Journal
summary: Understanding the variability of Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*) requires coordinated, multi-wavelength observations that span the electromagnetic spectrum. In this work, we focus on data from four key observatories: Chandra in the X-ray (2-8 keV), GRAVITY on the Very Large Telescope in the near-infrared (2.2 microns), Spitzer in the infrared (4.5 microns), and ALMA in the submillimeter (340 GHz). These multi-band observations are essential for probing the physics of accretion and emission near the black hole's event horizon, yet they suffer from irregular sampling, band-dependent noise, and substantial data gaps. These limitations complicate efforts to robustly identify flares and measure cross-band time lags, key diagnostics of the physical processes driving variability. To address this challenge, we introduce a diffusion-based generative model, for interpolating sparse, multivariate astrophysical time series. This represents the first application of score-based diffusion models to astronomical time series. We also present the first transformer-based model for light curve reconstruction that includes calibrated uncertainty estimates. The models are trained on simulated light curves constructed to match the statistical and observational characteristics of real Sgr A* data. These simulations capture correlated multi-band variability, realistic observation cadences, and wavelength-specific noise. We compare our models against a multi-output Gaussian Process. The diffusion model achieves superior accuracy and competitive calibration across both simulated and real datasets, demonstrating the promise of diffusion models for high-fidelity, uncertainty-aware reconstruction of multi-wavelength variability in Sgr A*.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces diffusion- and transformer-based models to reconstruct multi-wavelength light curves of Sgr A* and measure cross-band time lags, overcoming irregular sampling and noise in观测数据.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of irregular sampling, band-dependent noise, and data gaps when analyzing multi-wavelength observations of Sgr A*, which are crucial for studying accretion physics and event horizon-scale emission processes.
AI.method: Developed a diffusion-based generative model and a transformer-based model with uncertainty estimates for interpolating sparse, multi-variate astrophysical time series. Models were trained on simulations matching Sgr A* observational characteristics.
AI.result: The diffusion model outperformed Gaussian Processes in accuracy and calibration on both simulated and real data, enabling reliable flare detection and time lag measurements.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion models show great potential for high-fidelity, uncertainty-aware reconstruction of multi-wavelength variability in extreme astrophysical sources like Sgr A*.

title: Searching for a $P_{cs}(4200)$ state in the $Λ_b\toφη_cΛ$ reaction
summary: We propose the $Λ_b\toφη_c Λ$ reaction to observe a $P_{cs}$ state around $4200$ MeV, predicted at lower masses than expected from comparison with the $P_c$ states, stemming as a consequence of the important role played by coupled channels in the $P_{cs}$ case, which does not appear in the $P_c$ case. That state decays to $η_c Λ$ with a width of about $200$ keV. The reaction is related to $Λ_b^0\toφD_s^- Λ_c^+$, which has already been observed. We predict a branching fraction for $Λ_b\toφP_{cs}(4200)$; $P_{cs}\toη_c Λ$ of the order of $10^{-5}$, which is within present capabilities of the LHCb collaboration. The observation of this state would bring valuable light on the nature of the $P_c$ and $P_{cs}$ states and the role played by coupled channels in hadron structure and hadron reactions.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes observing a $P_{cs}(4200)$ state via the $Λ_b→φη_c Λ$ reaction, predicting a branching fraction of $10^{-5}$ and highlighting the role of coupled channels.
AI.motivation: To observe the predicted $P_{cs}$ state around 4200 MeV, which decays to $η_c Λ$ with a narrow width, and understand its relation to $P_c$ states and coupled-channel effects.
AI.method: The study uses the $Λ_b→φη_c Λ$ reaction linked to the experimentally observed $Λ_b^0→φD_s^- Λ_c^+$ process, calculating the branching ratio and decay dynamics.
AI.result: Predicts a branching fraction ~$10^{-5}$ detectable by LHCb, and emphasizes the importance of coupled channels in hadron structure studies.
AI.conclusion: Observing $P_{cs}(4200)$ would clarify the nature of $P_c/P_{cs}$ states and the coupled-channel mechanism's role in hadron reactions.

title: An Analytic Scale-dependent Dark Matter Profile and the Baryonic Tully-Fisher Relation
comment: The arXiv entry contains an extended appendix with all the SPARC galaxies. The journal version will not include the appendix, only some characteristic galaxies will be presented
summary: In this work we use the recently introduced concept of self-interacting dark matter with scale-dependent equation of state, and we provide an analytic model of dark matter that can produce viable rotation curves even for low-surface-brightness galaxies, irregular galaxies, low-luminosity spirals and dwarf galaxies, all known to challenge the cold dark matter description. The radius dependent effective equation of state of the self-interacting dark matter model we shall introduce is assumed to be an isothermal equation of state of the form $P(r)=K(r)\left(\frac{ρ(r)}{ρ_{\star}}\right)$, where the energy density will have the form $ρ(r)=\frac{ρ_0}{\left( 1+\frac{r^2}{α^2}\right)^{5/2}}$, while the entropy function $K(r)$ is $K(r)=\frac{K_0}{\left( 1+\frac{r^2}{α^2}\right)^{1/2}}$. The resulting model is confronted in detail with the SPARC galaxy data and 175 galaxies are used and tested. It proves that the analytic model can successfully produce the rotation curves of 116 galaxies, most of which are small mass spirals, irregular galaxies, low-surface-brightness and low-luminosity spirals and dwarf galaxies. On the other hand, 59 galaxies cannot be successfully described by our analytic model. We tested statistically the correlation between the parameter $K_0$ of the entropy function corresponding to the viable galaxies, and the flat rotation velocity $V_{flat}$ and the maximum rotation velocity $V_{max}$ of the galaxies from the SPARC data. We also examined the baryon mass $M_b$-$K_0$ relation and the luminosity $L$-$K_0$ relation. We have been able to produce the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation for the viable galaxies, directly from the correlation $K_0$-$M_b$ and $K_0$-$V_{flat}$, with the resulting relation being $M_b\sim V_{flat}^{4.026 \pm 0.371}$, however we failed to produce the canonical Tully-Fisher relation.

AI.tldr: The paper presents an analytic self-interacting dark matter model with a scale-dependent equation of state, which successfully predicts rotation curves for 116 out of 175 galaxies, particularly addressing challenges faced by the cold dark matter model for certain low-mass and low-luminosity galaxies. The model uses a radius-dependent isothermal equation of state and correlates parameters like K₀ with baryonic mass and rotation velocities, though fails to reproduce the canonical Tully-Fisher relation.
AI.motivation: To address the shortcomings of cold dark matter (CDM) in explaining rotation curves of low-surface-brightness galaxies, irregular galaxies, low-luminosity spirals, and dwarfs, the authors propose a self-interacting dark matter model with a scale-dependent equation of state that can be tested against observational data.
AI.method: A model with an isothermal equation of state P(r)=K(r)ρ(r)/ρ⋆, where ρ(r)=ρ₀/(1 + r²/α²)^{5/2} and K(r)=K₀/(1 + r²/α²)^{1/2} was constructed. The model was tested against SPARC data for 175 galaxies. Statistical correlations between K₀ and galaxy parameters (V_flat, V_max, M_b, L) were analyzed to derive relations like M_b ∼ V_flat^{4.026} but failed to reproduce the standard Tully-Fisher relation.
AI.result: The model successfully fits rotation curves for 116 galaxies (especially low-mass types), but 59 galaxies remain unexplained. A baryonic Tully-Fisher relation was derived from K₀ correlations, though not the canonical one. Statistical links between entropy parameter K₀ and key galaxy properties were established.
AI.conclusion: The self-interacting dark matter model effectively describes rotation curves in problematic galaxy types, offering an improvement over CDM for certain cases. However, failures in some galaxies and inability to reproduce the canonical Tully-Fisher relation suggest further refinement needed. The model provides new insights into dark matter behavior in low-mass galaxies and parameter correlations.

title: Gamma-ray Emission from the S147 Region: Indication of Escaping Cosmic Rays Interacting with Molecular Clouds
summary: We present a detailed analysis of $γ$-ray emission from the middle-aged supernova remnant (SNR) S147 (G180.0$-$1.7) using approximately 16.5 years of Fermi-LAT data. Spatially, a new extended $γ$-ray component distinct from the emission associated with the H$α$ filaments of the SNR shell is identified. This new component exhibits a strong spatial correlation with dense molecular clouds (MCs) identified in CO emission at Local Standard of Rest velocities of $0$-$5\,\mathrm{km\,s^{-1}}$. Spectrally, the cloud-associated emission implies an underlying cosmic-ray (CR) proton population described by a hard power law with an index of $Γ\approx 2.1$, compatible with the standard diffusive shock acceleration prediction. We interpret the $γ$-ray emission in this region with a hadronic scenario involving two distinct CR populations: trapped CRs reaccelerated within the radiative SNR shell as proposed in previous work, and escaping CRs illuminating the nearby MCs. The derived CR proton intensity in the MC region significantly exceeds the local Galactic background measured by AMS-02, strongly suggesting that the cloud is illuminated by particles accelerated by S147. These findings provide observational evidence for CR escape during the earlier evolutionary phases of this middle-aged SNR and highlight S147 as a promising candidate for detection at TeV energies by LHAASO.

AI.tldr: The study reveals a new γ-ray component from the SNR S147 linked to nearby molecular clouds, indicating cosmic-ray protons from the SNR escape and illuminate these clouds, providing evidence for cosmic-ray escape in middle-aged SNRs and potential TeV detection by LHAASO.
AI.motivation: To investigate γ-ray emission mechanisms in middle-aged supernova remnants and understand cosmic-ray acceleration/propagation by analyzing Fermi-LAT data of S147.
AI.method: Analyzed 16.5 years of Fermi-LAT data to spatially identify a new extended γ-ray component correlated with molecular clouds. Spectral analysis determined cosmic-ray proton spectra. Compared results with AMS-02 background measurements.
AI.result: Discovered cloud-associated γ-ray emission from CR protons with a hard power law spectrum (Γ≈2.1), indicating escape of CRs from SNR S147. CR intensity in clouds exceeds galactic background, confirming SNR origin.
AI.conclusion: S147 demonstrates early cosmic-ray escape phases, supports hadronic interaction models, and is a strong candidate for TeV observations by LHAASO to further study SNR-cosmic-ray connections.

title: Photon emission due to vacuum instability under the action of a quasi-constant electric field
comment: 19 pages, submitted for Proceedings of the conference Models in Quantum Field Theory (MQFT-2025)
summary: Following a nonperturbative formulation of strong-field QED developed in our earlier works, we consider photon emission accompanying vacuum instability under the action of a quasi-constant strong electric field of finite duration T. We construct closed formulas for the total probabilities and study the photon emission accompanying an electron-positron pair creation from a vacuum. We establish the domain of the applicability of the locally constant field approximation (LCFA) for the photon emission. We study angular and polarization distribution of the emission as well as emission characteristics in a high-frequency approximations with respect of 1/T. The results presented in this work is suitable to a further development of the LCFA proposed in [Phys. Rev. D 95, 076013 (2017)].

AI.tldr: The paper presents a nonperturbative framework for photon emission during vacuum instability in a finite-duration strong electric field, validates LCFA's applicability, and explores emission characteristics using high-frequency approximations.
AI.motivation: To address photon emission accompanying pair creation in strong fields, extending earlier QED work and refining LCFA's validity domain.
AI.method: Constructed closed-form total probabilities for photon emission, analyzed angular/polarization distributions, applied high-frequency approximations with respect to 1/T.
AI.result: Determined applicability domain of LCFA for photon emission, characterized radiation properties under finite-T fields, provided foundation for further LCFA development.
AI.conclusion: Validates LCFA under specific conditions and offers tools for improving theoretical models in strong-field QED scenarios.

title: Arrow of time problem in gravitational collapse
summary: We investigate the arrow of time problem in the context of gravitational collapse of radiating stars in higher dimensions for both neutral and charged matter. The interior spacetime is described by a shear-free spherically symmetric metric filled with a dissipative fluid. The exterior spacetime of the radiating star is taken as the higher dimensional Vaidya metric. We establish that the arrow of time associated with gravitational entropy is opposite to the thermodynamic arrow of time for all dimensions. The physical consequences of our results are considered. Our result conforms with previous studies on shear-free spherical collapse, which suggests, avoidance of the naked singularity as the end state results in a wrong arrow of time, indicating a fundamental problem with the local application of the Weyl curvature hypothesis.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the arrow of time in higher-dimensional gravitational collapse of radiating stars, finding that gravitational entropy's time arrow opposes the thermodynamic one, challenging the Weyl curvature hypothesis.
AI.motivation: To explore the arrow of time problem in higher dimensions during gravitational collapse, particularly addressing discrepancies between gravitational entropy and thermodynamic time arrows, and assessing implications for the Weyl curvature hypothesis.
AI.method: Analyzing shear-free spherical collapse models with dissipative fluids in higher dimensions, using interior metrics coupled with higher-dimensional Vaidya exteriors to compare entropy arrows.
AI.result: Confirmed that gravitational entropy's time direction is opposite to thermodynamic arrow across all dimensions, supporting prior findings that avoiding naked singularities causes temporal inconsistencies in local Weyl curvature applications.
AI.conclusion: The observed arrow disparity suggests fundamental issues with locally applying the Weyl curvature hypothesis, highlighting unresolved tensions between entropy arrows in gravitational collapse scenarios.

title: Mathematical Anatomy of Neutrino Decoherence in Red Turbulence: Fractional Calculus and Convergence of the Perturbative Series
summary: We present a comprehensive study of perturbation theory for neutrino decoherence in power-law correlated turbulent matter, establishing rigorous convergence criteria and providing detailed numerical validation. Starting from the exact Laplace-space solution derived from the generalized master equation with memory kernel $K(t) \propto t^{-ν}e^{-t/τ_c}$, we develop a systematic perturbation expansion in the turbulence strength parameter $ξ$. The expansion is performed around the high-density matter basis where $\cos 2θ_m \approx 1$, rather than the vacuum basis, reflecting the physical conditions in supernova cores. We obtain explicit expressions for the first few perturbation terms and derive the general structure of higher-order terms, which involve Mittag-Leffler functions that emerge from the fractional dynamics. Using high-precision numerical methods (multiple-precision arithmetic and asymptotic expansions), we analyze the convergence radius and rate of the perturbation series. We find that for $ξ< ξ_c \approx 0.8$, the series converges with error decreasing geometrically. For $ξ= 0.16$ (typical supernova conditions), third-order perturbation theory achieves $\sim 1\%$ accuracy. We provide practical guidelines for applying perturbation theory to realistic astrophysical scenarios and validate all analytical results with extensive numerical computations. Our work clarifies several subtle aspects of the perturbative approach that were not addressed in the original literature, offering a complete toolkit for researchers studying neutrino-turbulence interactions. In particular, we systematically address the ultraviolet divergence of the correlation function at short time scales for spectral indices $ν\geq 1$, introducing a physical small-scale cutoff regularization that ensures mathematical rigor for the fractional master equation and perturbative expansion.

AI.tldr: The paper develops a rigorous perturbation theory framework for neutrino decoherence in power-law correlated turbulent matter, establishing convergence criteria and validating through numerical methods. It addresses previous theoretical gaps, such as ultraviolet divergence, and provides practical guidelines for astrophysical applications.
AI.motivation: To provide a mathematically sound and numerically validated perturbation theory for neutrino-turbulence interactions in environments like supernova cores, addressing unresolved issues like convergence and ultraviolet divergence.
AI.method: The authors derive a Laplace-space solution from a generalized master equation with memory kernel K(t) ∝ t^{-ν}e^{-t/τ_c}, then perform a perturbation expansion in turbulence strength ξ around the high-density matter basis. They compute explicit terms up to third order, analyze convergence using Mittag-Leffler functions, and apply numerical methods for validation.
AI.result: The perturbation series converges for ξ < 0.8 with geometric error reduction. Third-order theory achieves ~1% accuracy at ξ=0.16 (typical supernova conditions). The introduced cutoff regularization resolves ultraviolet divergence for ν ≥ 1.
AI.conclusion: The study offers a complete, rigorously tested perturbative framework that enables accurate modeling of neutrino decoherence in turbulent astrophysical environments, serving as a reliable toolkit for future research in neutrino-turbulence interactions.

title: Enhancing online estimation of CBC parameters with the low-latency MBTA analysis
summary: In this paper, we describe the procedure implemented in the Multi-Band Template Analysis (MBTA) search pipeline to produce online posterior distributions of compact binary coalescence (CBC) gravitational-wave parameters. This procedure relies on an SNR optimizer technique, which consists of filtering dense local template banks. We present how these banks are constructed using information from the initial detection and detail how the results of the filtering are used to estimate source parameters and provide posterior distributions. We demonstrate the performance of our procedure on simulations and compare our source parameter estimates with the results from the first part of the fourth observing run (O4a) recently released by the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA (LVK) collaboration.

AI.tldr: This paper outlines the Multi-Band Template Analysis (MBTA) pipeline for producing real-time posterior distributions of compact binary coalescence gravitational-wave parameters using SNR optimization and dense local template banks, validated against simulations and LVK's O4a data.
AI.motivation: To enable rapid and accurate estimation of gravitational-wave source parameters during live observations, improving upon existing methods for parameter estimation in gravitational-wave astronomy.
AI.method: The MBTA pipeline uses an SNR optimizer technique with dense local template banks constructed from initial detection data. Filtered results are used to estimate parameters and generate posterior distributions through statistical analysis.
AI.result: Validation with simulations showed accurate parameter recovery. Comparisons with LVK's O4a data demonstrated alignment between MBTA estimates and collaboration results, proving the method's reliability for real-time analysis.
AI.conclusion: The MBTA pipeline effectively provides timely and precise parameter posteriors for CBC events, enhancing the capability for real-time gravitational-wave astronomy and follow-up observations.

title: Decoding $Z_c(4430)$ and $Z_c(4200)$: The role of $P$-wave charmed mesons
summary: In this work, we perform a systematic investigation of the hidden-charm tetraquark states with $I^G(J^{PC})=1^+(1^{+-})$ within the hadronic molecular picture, placing particular emphasis on systems composed of an $S$-wave $(D, D^*)$ meson and a $P$-wave $(D_0^*(2300), D_1(2430), D_1(2420), D_2^*(2460))$ meson. Adopting the One-Boson Exchange potential, we solve the Schrödinger equation in momentum space via the Complex Scaling Method. A crucial feature of our approach is the rigorous treatment of the unstable nature of the $P$-wave constituents by incorporating three-body decay effects arising from self-energy corrections and the static limit approximation. Our results demonstrate that these three-body dynamics play a crucial role in determining the pole positions, specifically in reproducing the large decay widths observed experimentally. We identify several broad resonances in the $D^*\bar{D}_1(2420)$ and $D^*\bar{D}_2^*(2460)$ systems as candidates for the $Z_c(4430)$, while the significantly broader resonances in the $D\bar{D}_0^*(2300)$ and $D\bar{D}_1(2430)$ sectors are suggested as candidates for the $Z_c(4200)$. Focusing on the $D^*\bar{D}_2^*(2460)$ assignment as a specific case study, we further analyze the line shape of the $Z_c(4430)$ candidate using a Flatté-like parametrization with energy-dependent self-energy terms, providing predictions for its open-charm decay modes to guide future experimental searches.

AI.tldr: The paper examines hidden-charm tetraquark states with quantum numbers I^G(J^{PC})=1^+(1^{+-}) by modeling systems of S-wave D/D* mesons and P-wave D0*(2300)/D1/D2* mesons using a one-boson exchange potential and complex scaling method. Key findings include identifying broad resonances as candidates for Zc(4430) and Zc(4200), emphasizing three-body dynamics' role in pole positions and decay widths.
AI.motivation: Investigate hidden-charm tetraquark states to understand their nature as hadronic molecules, address the mechanisms behind large decay widths observed experimentally, and validate potential candidates for known states like Zc(4430) and Zc(4200).
AI.method: Uses the one-boson exchange potential to solve the Schrödinger equation in momentum space with the complex scaling method, incorporating self-energy corrections and static limit approximation to handle unstable P-wave mesons' three-body decay effects.
AI.result: Identifies broad resonances in specific meson-meson systems as Zc(4430) and Zc(4200) candidates. Demonstrates that three-body dynamics significantly influence pole positions and reproduce experimental decay widths. Provides Flatté parametrization predictions for Zc(4430)'s open-charm decay modes.
AI.conclusion: Three-body interactions are crucial for accurately modeling tetraquark states. The identified resonances' assignments validate the molecular picture, while predictions for decay modes offer guidance for future experimental validation.

title: Quantum Cosmology as a Hydrogen atom: Discrete $Λ$ and cyclic Universes from Wheeler-DeWitt quantization
comment: 18 pages, 3 figures. Accepted for publication in Classical and Quantum Gravity
summary: Building upon our recently established correspondence between quantum cosmology and the hydrogen atom [1], we investigate the specific sector of a negative cosmological constant ($Λ< 0$) in a flat FLRW universe with dust. While the positive $Λ$ sector [1] yields a continuous spectrum and a single bounce, we show here that the negative $Λ$ sector leads to a discrete spectrum of energy eigenvalues, effectively quantizing the cosmological constant. Within this dual description, the operator-ordering ambiguity parameter appears as the azimuthal quantum number of the hydrogen atom. A skewed Bohr correspondence emerges for the bound states, matching classical evolution at large volumes but deviating near the bounce. By constructing wave packets from these bound states, we demonstrate that the classical Big Bang and Big Crunch singularities are resolved, and the universe oscillates between quantum bounces and classical turnaround points. The expectation values of the observables indicate a cyclic universe -- with vanishing Hubble parameter at turnarounds -- undergoing quantum bounces. This exactly solvable model offers a tractable setting to explore quantum gravitational effects in cosmology. We analyze the properties of this cyclic universe, contrasting its bound-state dynamics with the scattering states of the de Sitter case.

AI.tldr: The paper explores a quantum cosmology model with a negative cosmological constant (Λ < 0) in a flat FLRW universe with dust, finding discrete energy eigenvalues that quantize Λ. It connects this to the hydrogen atom's azimuthal quantum number, resolves cosmic singularities via quantum bounces, and describes a cyclic universe oscillating between quantum states.
AI.motivation: To extend prior work on quantum cosmology's correspondence with the hydrogen atom to the negative Λ case, addressing differences from the positive Λ scenario (continuous spectrum vs. discrete eigenvalues), and to explore singularity resolution and quantum gravitational effects in a tractable model.
AI.method: Analyze the negative Λ sector using operator-ordering ambiguity parameters mapped to hydrogen's azimuthal quantum number. Construct wave packets from bound states to model universe dynamics. Compare bound-state (negative Λ) and scattering-state (positive Λ) behaviors.
AI.result: Discrete energy eigenvalues quantize Λ; singularity resolution via quantum bounces replacing Big Bang/ Crunch. Cyclic universe emerges with vanishing Hubble parameter at turnarounds, validated via expectation values. The model provides an exactly solvable system for quantum gravity studies.
AI.conclusion: The model successfully unifies quantum cosmology with hydrogen-like quantization, demonstrating singularity resolution and cyclic behavior. It contrasts sharply with de Sitter's scattering states, offering insights into quantum gravitational dynamics in manageable scenarios.

title: Probing the Diversity of Type Ia Supernova Remnants in 3-D Hydrodynamic Simulations with X-ray Spectral Synthesis
summary: Type Ia supernovae (SNe), thermonuclear explosions of white dwarfs in binary systems, are widely used as standard candles owing to the empirical width-luminosity relation of their light curves. Recent theoretical and observational studies indicate a diversity of progenitor systems and explosion mechanisms. In the supernova remnant (SNR) phase, the diversity in Fe-K$α$ centroid energies and line luminosities suggests variations in the underlying explosion mechanisms. X-ray spectra of SNRs, which trace shocked ejecta and the surrounding medium, are crucial diagnostics of progenitor systems and explosion physics. Thanks to recent advances in spectroscopy with XRISM, high-resolution X-ray spectroscopy enables 3-D diagnostics, including line-of-sight velocities. In this study, we perform 3-D hydrodynamic simulations of SNRs from six Type Ia explosion models: two each of pure deflagration, delayed detonation, and double detonation. Each model is evolved for 1000 years in a uniform medium, consistently accounting for non-equilibrium ionization. Our efficient numerical scheme enables systematic parameter surveys in full 3-D. From these models, we synthesize X-ray spectra with $\sim$1 eV resolution, exceeding XRISM/Resolve's spectral resolution. This work presents the first calculation of X-ray spectra for Type Ia SNRs derived from 3-D hydrodynamic simulations that follow the evolution self-consistently from the SN phase into the SNR phase. Our results show inter-model diversity in the X-ray spectra. Asymmetric, red- and blueshifted line profiles arise from the 3-D ejecta distributions. These findings demonstrate that 3-D SNR modeling can reproduce the observed diversity of Type Ia SNRs and provide qualitative constraints on progenitor systems and explosion mechanisms.

AI.tldr: This study uses 3D hydrodynamic simulations to model X-ray spectra of Type Ia supernova remnants (SNRs), demonstrating that explosion mechanisms and progenitor systems can be inferred from observational differences in Fe-Kα lines and asymmetric line profiles.
AI.motivation: Type Ia SNe are crucial cosmological tools, but their diversity in progenitors and explosion mechanisms remain poorly understood. Observational diversity in Fe-Kα line features suggests underlying physical differences, and X-ray spectroscopy (enhanced by XRISM) offers a way to diagnose these.
