AI.method: 3D hydrodynamic simulations of 6 Type Ia SN explosion models (deflagration, delayed detonation, double detonation) followed for 1000 years in uniform medium with non-equilibrium ionization. Synthesized X-ray spectra with 1eV resolution matching XRISM's capabilities.
AI.result: Models produce distinct X-ray spectra with asymmetric red/blueshifted Fe-Kα lines linked to 3D ejecta structures. These match observed SNR diversity, offering constraints on explosion mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: 3D SNR modeling provides critical diagnostics for distinguishing Type Ia SN progenitors and explosion physics through high-resolution X-ray spectroscopy. This approach enables systematic exploration of parameter spaces and improves interpretability of SNR observations.

title: The Need for Ultra High Resolution X-ray Imaging
summary: This paper discusses the broad science case for obtaining milliarcsecond to microarcsecond astronomical imaging resolution in the soft to medium-energy X-ray band (~0.5 to ~8 keV). Astronomy across much of the electromagnetic spectrum has been fundamentally transformed with a rapid increase in ground-based and space-based capabilities to examine celestial objects on small scales that relate directly to their relevant physical processes. X-ray imaging capabilities, however, have fallen far behind observations at longer wavelengths. As such, without decisive advances in X-ray imaging, we will be unable to uncover key phenomena on the smallest astrophysical scales, leaving entire classes of high-energy discoveries beyond our reach. Here we describe several science goals for which high quality X-ray imaging is crucial and the status of some current technologies or mission concepts that would be required for these advances. In particular, we discuss the Accretion Explorer, a mission architecture under current study for a dispersed aperture X-ray interferometer.

AI.tldr: This paper advocates for the development of advanced X-ray imaging technologies, particularly focusing on the Accretion Explorer, a dispersed aperture X-ray interferometer, to achieve milliarcsecond to microarcsecond resolution in the 0.5–8 keV X-ray band. Such advancements are critical to unlocking key astrophysical phenomena currently beyond our observational reach.
AI.motivation: X-ray imaging has lagged behind other wavelengths in resolution, preventing insights into small-scale astrophysical processes. The paper motivates the need for superior X-ray imaging to explore phenomena like black hole accretion, neutron star surfaces, and high-energy cosmic events that require unprecedented spatial resolution.
AI.method: The paper outlines several key science goals enabled by high-resolution X-ray imaging and evaluates current and proposed technologies, including the Accretion Explorer's dispersed aperture interferometer design. It combines scientific requirements with the technical feasibility of next-generation X-ray missions.
AI.result: Advancing X-ray imaging to milliarcsecond/microarcsecond scales could reveal details of compact objects, jet formation, and extreme gravitational environments. The Accretion Explorer concept represents a viable path forward, though technological challenges remain.
AI.conclusion: Urgent investment in X-ray imaging technology is necessary to fulfill pressing astrophysical research objectives. The realization of concepts like the Accretion Explorer is critical for achieving the required resolution breakthroughs in X-ray astronomy.

title: Graviton energy spectra arising from the KSVZ axion model
summary: Axion, the goldstone boson arising from the spontaneous breaking of a global $U(1)$ Peccei-Quinn symmetry, provides a dynamical solution to the strong CP problem and is an excellent dark matter candidate. Various experiments are designed to search for the axion, however no confirmative signal has been observed. On the other hand, there are also hypothetical heavy particles in axion models, such as the heavy scalar $s$, which is the CP-even component of the complex scalar that carries $U(1)_{PQ}$ charge, and the vector-like heavy quark (VLQ) in the Kim-Shifman-Vainshtein-Zakharov~(KSVZ) axion model. Studying signals induced by them are helpful for axion searches. In this paper, we calculate the graviton bremsstrahlung energy spectrum arising from the decay of the heavy scalar or VLQ in the KSVZ model. The result shows that these heavy particles can emit ultrahigh-frequency gravitational waves (GWs), with the peak frequency depending on the model's parameter inputs. In addition, the graviton spectrum is distinguished from the thermal GW background at high frequencies if there is an early matter-dominated era induced by these heavy particles. Future measurements of ultrahigh-frequency GWs may provide indirect evidence for the KSVZ axion.

AI.tldr: The paper explores gravitational wave signatures from heavy particles in the KSVZ axion model, offering a potential indirect detection method for axions through high-frequency GWs.
AI.motivation: To provide an alternative approach for axion detection by studying gravitational wave signals from heavy particles (heavy scalar or vector-like quarks) in the KSVZ model, as direct axion searches have not yielded conclusive results.
AI.method: Calculated graviton bremsstrahlung energy spectra from the decay of heavy scalar or VLQs in the KSVZ model, analyzing their gravitational wave emission characteristics, especially under an early matter-dominated era.
AI.result: The heavy particles emit ultrahigh-frequency gravitational waves with peak frequency dependent on model parameters; these signals can distinguish themselves from thermal backgrounds at high frequencies.
AI.conclusion: Future measurements of high-frequency gravitational waves could indirectly confirm the existence of the KSVZ axion model's heavy particles and support axion physics.

title: GUP effects on Hawking temperature in a hot NUT Kerr Newman Kasuya Anti de Sitter black hole
comment: The manuscript consists of 14 pages and 8 figures
summary: In this work, we use the generalised Klein-Gordon Equation in curved spacetime with an electromagnetic field to investigate the tunnelling phenomenon of scalar particles originating from the hot NUT Kerr Newman Kasuya Anti de Sitter (KNKNK AdS) black hole. Using the tunnelling formalism, we obtain a modified Hawking temperature different from previous works due to the quantum gravity effect for the charged Dirac particle at the HNKNK AdS black hole's horizon. We find that the modified Hawking temperature is affected by the cosmological constant, magnetic mass, electric and magnetic charges. We demonstrate that a significant number of discontinuities exist in the heat capacities of the HNKNK AdS, indicating that the black hole system becomes unstable as the black hole size decreases.

AI.tldr: The paper uses the generalized Klein-Gordon equation to study scalar particle tunneling from a NUT Kerr Newman Kasuya Anti-de Sitter black hole, deriving a modified Hawking temperature influenced by cosmological constant, magnetic mass, and charges. Results show black hole instability via heat capacity discontinuities.
AI.motivation: Investigate quantum gravity effects on tunneling phenomena and black hole thermodynamics in complex spacetimes (KNKNK AdS), addressing limitations of previous Hawking temperature calculations.
AI.method: Applied generalized Klein-Gordon equation in curved spacetime with electromagnetic fields to analyze tunneling; used tunneling formalism to compute modified Hawking temperature considering quantum gravity effects.
AI.result: Derived a new Hawking temperature formula differing from prior works, showing dependencies on cosmological constant, magnetic mass, and charges. Found heat capacity discontinuities indicating instability as black hole size decreases.
AI.conclusion: Quantum gravity effects significantly alter black hole thermodynamic properties, with instability arising from heat capacity issues as black holes shrink, highlighting the need for further quantum gravity studies in black hole physics.

title: A multi-technique search for year-scale $γ$-ray quasi-periodic modulation in the high-redshift FSRQ PKS~2052$-$47
summary: We investigate year-scale quasi-periodic oscillations in the $γ$-ray emission of the high-redshift flat-spectrum radio quasar PKS~2052$-$47 using monthly binned \emph{Fermi}-LAT data spanning MJD~54727.99--58507.99. To assess the statistical significance of periodic features embedded in red-noise-dominated variability, we apply several complementary timing techniques, including the Lomb--Scargle periodogram, weighted wavelet $Z$-transform, date-compensated discrete Fourier transform, REDFIT assuming an AR(1) process, and damped random walk modelling. The analyses reveal a dominant quasi-periodic modulation on a timescale of $\sim600$--630~d, together with a secondary longer-timescale feature near $\sim1050$--1110~d. Monte Carlo simulations show that the shorter-period signal exceeds the highest local confidence levels, while the longer modulation reaches $\gtrsim99$ per cent local significance in several tests; independent DRW-based simulations place both peaks above the $4σ$ envelope in the Lomb--Scargle analysis. Spectral-window diagnostics indicate that the detected periodicities are not artefacts of uneven sampling, and a sliding-window analysis shows that the QPO power is episodic across the $\sim11$~yr baseline. We discuss possible physical interpretations in terms of geometric Doppler modulation associated with jet precession or helical motion, accretion-driven instabilities, and SMBBH-induced dynamics.

AI.tldr: The study reveals quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) in the γ-ray emission of PKS 2052−47 with periods of ~600-630 days and ~1050-1110 days. Statistical analyses confirm the significance of these signals, ruling out sampling effects. Possible origins include jet precession, accretion disk instabilities, or a supermassive binary black hole system.
AI.motivation: To explore potential periodic features in high-redshift blazar variability and distinguish them from red noise, using advanced timing techniques to confirm their statistical significance.
AI.method: Monthly binned Fermi-LAT γ-ray data spanning ~11 years were analyzed with multiple methods: Lomb-Scargle periodogram, weighted wavelet Z-transform, date-compensated DFT, REDFIT (AR(1) model), and damped random walk modeling. Monte Carlo simulations and spectral-window diagnostics tested significance and robustness of periodicities.
AI.result: Dominant ~600-day QPO and secondary ~1100-day modulation detected. Shorter period exceeds 99% local significance, with both peaks surpassing 4σ in Lomb-Scargle. Power varies episodically over the observation period.
AI.conclusion: Observed QPOs likely originate from relativistic jet dynamics (precession/helical motion), accretion instabilities, or SMBBH orbital motion. Requires multiwavelength follow-up and modeling to distinguish between mechanisms.

title: The strangest non-strange meson is not so strange: Phase shift analysis reveals the geometric origin of the $f_0(500)$ residue phase
comment: Significant revision and extension of arXiv:2005.11564 [hep-ph]. Includes updated analysis, additional authors, and improved methodology as validated in Phys. Lett. B 872 (2026) 140136
summary: The $f_0(500)$ meson is often labeled a "non-Breit-Wigner" resonance due to the large background phase required for its description. By fitting elastic phase shifts of the $f_0(500)$, $ρ(770)$, and $Δ(1232)$, we extract the effective background phase $φ_\mathrm{B}$ and uncover an empirical regularity within our formalism: $φ_\mathrm{B}$ is equal to the angle subtended by the pole and the threshold $φ_0$. This implies the residue phase is geometrically constrained to be $θ\approx 2φ_0$. The anomalous nature of the $f_0(500)$ thus arises from the proximity of its pole to the $ππ$ threshold. A unified scaling relation confirms the $f_0(500)$ behaves as a standard Breit-Wigner resonance.

AI.tldr: Study shows the $f_0(500)$ meson, previously considered a non-Breit-Wigner resonance due to its large background phase, actually follows Breit-Wigner behavior when accounting for its proximity to the $ππ$ threshold and geometric constraints on residue phases.
AI.motivation: To resolve the anomaly of the $f_0(500)$ meson's resonance characteristics and understand its deviation from standard Breit-Wigner descriptions through analysis of background phases and pole positions.
AI.method: Fitting elastic phase shifts of $f_0(500)$, $ρ(770)$, and $Δ(1232)$ resonances to extract effective background phase $φ_B$, comparing it to the threshold angle $φ_0$, and deriving scaling relations.
AI.result: Found $φ_B = φ_0$, residue phase $θ≈2φ_0$, confirming the $f_0(500)$ adheres to Breit-Wigner formalism when considering geometric constraints from its pole's proximity to threshold.
AI.conclusion: The $f_0(500)$ meson's anomalous behavior originates from its threshold proximity, not intrinsic non-resonant properties, aligning it with standard resonance models under proper consideration.

title: Violation of the Leggett-Garg inequality in photon-graviton conversion
summary: The Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI) is a temporal analogue of Bell's inequality and provides a quantitative test of the nonclassicality of a system through its violation. We analytically investigate the violation of the LGI in the context of photon-graviton conversion in a magnetic field background, motivated by its potential applications to testing the nonclassicality of gravity. When gravitational perturbations are quantized as gravitons, the conversion of an initial single photon state gives rise to a superposition of photon and graviton states. We show that the temporal correlations obtained from successive projective measurements on the photon-graviton system violate the LGI. Observation of such a violation would provide a novel avenue for probing the quantum nature of gravity.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the violation of the Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI) in photon-graviton conversion within a magnetic field, offering a potential method to test the quantum nature of gravity through temporal correlations.
AI.motivation: To provide a quantitative test for the nonclassicality of gravity using the LGI, which is a temporal version of Bell's inequality.
AI.method: Analytical investigation of photon-graviton conversion in a magnetic field, focusing on temporal correlations from projective measurements.
AI.result: Violation of the LGI was shown in the photon-graviton system, indicating nonclassical behavior.
AI.conclusion: Observing LGI violation could serve as a novel approach to probing quantum aspects of gravity.

title: Interaction of Black Hole Magnetospheres with Inclined Ambient Fields
summary: Magnetic fields play a central role in black hole astrophysics, powering relativistic jets and other energetic phenomena. While near-horizon magnetic field is usually assumed to originate from the accretion flow, additional large-scale magnetic fields - such as those supplied by a companion neutron star in stellar-mass binaries or by galactic fields around supermassive black holes - may also affect the horizon-threading flux. In this work, we study the superposition of a weak arbitrarily inclined external uniform magnetic field with the internal Blandford-Znajek split-monopole field around a Schwarzschild black hole. This setup generically gives rise to magnetic null points, where the total field vanishes. We compute the magnetic flux through an arbitrarily tilted hemisphere of the event horizon and show that the flux can be substantially suppressed by the external field. In the axisymmetric case, the flux can even vanish completely. However, with nonzero inclination, complete cancellation becomes impossible, despite significant reduction. We further explore the ionization and subsequent particle acceleration from a Keplerian accretion disk, finding that efficient collimated outflows persist even under significant field inclination. We show that the acceleration is critically dependent on the external field orientation, with the escape fraction maximized at non-zero inclinations due to the destabilization of trapping zones and minimized in the anti-aligned configuration, where closed magnetic loops effectively suppress the outflow. We discuss the astrophysical implications of these findings, proposing that geometric flux cancellation can serve as a mechanism for jet quenching in compact binaries and offering an explanation for the lack of a prominent large-scale jet in Sgr A*.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how external magnetic fields influence the magnetic flux around black holes and their impact on jet formation. It finds that external fields can suppress the horizon flux, with complete cancellation in axisymmetric cases but not when inclined. Particle acceleration from accretion disks still occurs, with jet efficiency dependent on field orientation.
AI.motivation: The study aims to understand the role of external magnetic fields in modifying the intrinsic magnetic fields near black holes, particularly their effect on jet production and energy extraction mechanisms like the Blandford-Znajek process.
AI.method: The authors analyze the superposition of a weak external uniform magnetic field with the internal Blandford-Znajek split-monopole field around a Schwarzschild black hole. They compute the magnetic flux through tilted hemispheres of the event horizon and model ionization/particle acceleration from a Keplerian accretion disk.
AI.result: External fields significantly reduce the horizon flux; axisymmetric cases allow complete cancellation, but inclinations prevent total cancellation yet still suppress flux. Outflows persist with acceleration efficiency peaking at non-zero inclinations and minimized in anti-aligned fields due to trapping zone destabilization or closed loops forming.
AI.conclusion: Geometric flux cancellation by external fields can quench jets in systems like compact binaries and explain jet suppression in Sgr A*. This provides insights into varying jet behaviors observed in different black hole environments.

title: Investigation on the photoproduction of bottom-charmed baryon within NRQCD
summary: We present a further theoretical study of the orbital $P$-wave bottom-charmed baryon within the framework of nonrelativistic QCD (NRQCD), considering both the direct photoproduction channel $γ+γ\rightarrow Ξ_{bc} +\bar{c}+\bar{b}$ and the resolved photoproduction channel $γ+g \rightarrow Ξ_{bc} +\bar{c}+\bar{b}$. At future linear colliders, ILC and CLIC, the initial photons can be emitted from the laser back-scattering (LBS) and then the parton gluon can be emitted from the photon. The formation of $Ξ_{bc}$ can be modeled in two-step: a compact diquark state $\langle bc\rangle[n]$ is formed first and subsequently captures a light quark from the vacuum to hadronize into the baryon $Ξ_{bc}$. The color and spin quantum number $[n]$ of $\langle bc\rangle$-diquark can be $[{}^3S_1]_{\bar{\textbf{3}}/\textbf{6}}$, $[{}^1S_0]_{\bar{\textbf{3}}/\textbf{6}}$, $[{}^1P_1]_{\bar{\textbf{3}}/\textbf{6}}$ or $[{}^3P_J]_{\bar{\textbf{3}}/\textbf{6}}$ with $J=0,1,2$. Based on the collision energies and design luminosity of ILC and CLIC, the cross sections, the differential distributions and the estimated produced events of $Ξ_{bc}$ baryon have been analyzed. The results show that the contribution of the orbital excited $P$-wave $Ξ_{bc}$ baryon can reach 7%-9% of the $S$-wave, providing a non-negligible contributions.

AI.tldr: The study investigates orbital $P$-wave bottom-charmed baryon production via photoproduction processes at ILC and CLIC colliders, showing $P$-wave contributions account for 7%-9% of $S$-wave yields.
AI.motivation: To theoretically explore the role of orbital $P$-wave states in bottom-charmed baryon photoproduction and quantify their feasibility for observation at future electron-positron colliders.
AI.method: NRQCD framework is applied to analyze direct ($\gamma+\gamma$) and resolved ($\gamma+g$) photoproduction channels. The $Ξ_{bc}$ formation involves a two-step process: forming a compact $bc$-diquark in various spin-color states followed by light-quark capture. Cross sections and event yields are computed using collider parameters.
AI.result: Computed cross sections show $P$-wave $Ξ_{bc}$ contributes 7-9% of the $S$-wave counterpart, significant enough for potential detection at ILC/CLIC with their planned luminosities.
AI.conclusion: Orbital $P$-wave contributions in $Ξ_{bc}$ production are non-negligible and their experimental identification would validate NRQCD predictions, offering insights into exotic hadron formations.

title: Ultraviolet Signatures of Jet-Ejecta Interaction in Early Kilonovae: Prediction from Realistic Atomic Opacities
summary: We investigate the signature of the jet-ejecta interaction in early kilonova (t < 1day) using detailed atomic opacities developed in Banerjee et al. (2020, 2024), appropriate for early times (t~1hour after merger). We explore jets with different powers and opening angles. We find that the presence of the jet shifts the spectral peak to longer wavelengths, with the strongest effect near the polar viewing angle. This occurs because the jet creates a thin, low-density outer layer ahead of the bulk ejecta. The opacity of this layer can be as high as kappa ~200 cm2/g, causing photons to escape from cooler, faster-moving outer layer rather than from the hot inner ejecta. The bolometric light curves likewise exhibit a clear imprint of the jet-ejecta interaction, showing suppressed early-time luminosity near polar viewing angles compared to the equatorial one, as the photosphere resides in this thin layer where radioactive heating is lower than in the bulk ejecta. These signatures are also evident in multi-color light curves, particularly in the ultraviolet and u-bands. In the Swift-UVW2 band at t~= 0.15 days for a source at 100 Mpc, the ultraviolet luminosities can reach ~ 19.5 mag if no jet is present, while the presence of the jet can make it fainter by ~ 2.5 mag. The strongest observational signature occurs in the UVEX-NUV, Swift-UVW2, and UVM2 bands, which remains detectable out to viewing angles of ~ 60 deg for t <=1 days. Rapid follow-up with future ultraviolet facilities, such as ULTRASAT and UVEX, will provide powerful probes of jet-ejecta interaction through early-time kilonova observations.

AI.tldr: The paper examines how jets from a neutron star merger interact with the surrounding ejecta in the early phases of a kilonova event, finding that the jet's presence significantly affects observable light curves and spectral signatures, especially in ultraviolet bands.
AI.motivation: Understand the observational signatures of jet-ejecta interactions in early kilonova events to better interpret future observations and probe the physics of these extreme astrophysical events.
AI.method: The authors use detailed atomic opacity models (from Banerjee et al.) to simulate jets with varying power and opening angles. They analyze spectral shifts, bolometric and multi-color light curves under different viewing angles.
AI.result: Jets create a low-density outer layer causing spectral peaks to shift to longer wavelengths, most pronounced at polar angles. This leads to suppressed UV luminosity at polar angles compared to equatorial views. UVEX-NUV, Swift-UVW2, and UVM2 bands show detectable signatures up to 60 degrees viewing angle within a day post-merger.
AI.conclusion: Future UV观测 facilities like ULTRASAT and UVEX will enable detection of jet-ejecta interactions via early kilonova UV observations, offering new insights into jet dynamics and merger processes.

title: Pathology of the Unified Dark Sectors in Modified General Relativity
comment: 27 pages, 1 figure, to appear in Classical and Quantum Gravity (CQG)
summary: This paper presents a comprehensive stability analysis of the black hole solution within Modified General Relativity (MGR), a theory proposing a unified geometric description of dark matter (DM) and dark energy (DE). A rigorous gauge-invariant formalism is employed to analyze gravitational perturbations of the extended Schwarzschild metric. The central finding is a critical pathology within the polar perturbation sector, where metric fluctuations couple to the theory's fundamental line element field. This coupling is governed by a factor that, while well-behaved at the horizon, diverges powerfully in the far-field limit as a direct consequence of the theory's non-asymptotically flat nature. This indicates a strong infrared instability that overwhelms perturbations at large distances. In stark contrast, the axial perturbation sector is found to be completely stable. This dichotomy proves that the instability is not inherent to the background metric but is specifically generated by the novel coupling mechanism encoding MGR's unified dark sectors. The results reveal a fundamental strong-coupling problem within the MGR framework, challenging its physical viability as an alternative to Einstein's General Relativity (EGR).

AI.tldr: The paper identifies a critical instability in Modified General Relativity's black hole solutions due to a novel coupling in the polar perturbation sector, raising concerns about the theory's viability.
AI.motivation: To assess the stability of MGR's black hole solutions and evaluate the theory's viability as a unified description of dark matter and dark energy.
AI.method: Used gauge-invariant formalism to analyze gravitational perturbations of the extended Schwarzschild metric in MGR, examining both polar and axial sectors.
AI.result: Polar perturbations exhibit a strong infrared instability due to a divergent coupling in the far-field, while axial perturbations remain stable, indicating a theory-specific issue.
AI.conclusion: MGR's unified dark sectors introduce a fundamental strong-coupling problem, challenging its validity as an alternative to General Relativity.

title: Gravitational wave detection via photon-graviton scattering and quantum interference
summary: We present a fully quantum field-theoretic framework for gravitational wave (GW) detection in which the interaction is described as photon-graviton scattering. In this picture, the GW acts as a coherent background that induces inelastic energy exchanges with the electromagnetic field - analogous to the Stokes and anti-Stokes shifts in Raman spectroscopy. We propose a detection scheme sensitive to this microscopic mechanism based on Hong-Ou-Mandel interference. We show that the scattering-induced phase shifts render frequency-entangled photon pairs distinguishable, spoiling their destructive quantum interference. GW signal is thus encoded in the modulation of photon coincidence rates rather than classical field intensity, offering a complementary quantum probe of the gravitational universe that recovers the standard classical response in the macroscopic limit.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a quantum field-theoretic framework for gravitational wave detection using photon-graviton scattering and Hong-Ou-Mandel interference, where GWs modulate photon coincidence rates through phase shifts, providing a quantum detection method that aligns with classical results in the macroscopic limit.
AI.motivation: To develop a fully quantum approach for detecting gravitational waves that captures microscopic energy exchanges and offers a complementary method to classical techniques.
AI.method: The framework models GW detection via photon-graviton scattering, analogous to Raman spectroscopy's Stokes/anti-Stokes shifts. It uses Hong-Ou-Mandel interference with frequency-entangled photon pairs to detect phase shifts caused by GWs, affecting coincidence rates.
AI.result: The proposed scheme shows that GWs induce distinguishability in photon pairs, suppressing quantum interference. The detection encodes GW signals in photon coincidence rate modulations, consistent with classical responses at macroscopic scales.
AI.conclusion: This quantum detection method provides a new probe for gravitational waves, offering sensitivity advantages and complementing classical detection by leveraging quantum effects, while recovering classical results in the appropriate limit.

title: Matter around Schwarzschild black holes in scalar-tensor theories: Absorption and Scattering
summary: We investigate the absorption and scattering by a Schwarzschild black hole in scalar--tensor theories of gravity, where the coupling between matter and the scalar field induces different models for the effective mass of the scalar field. In model~I, a Bondi-type mass model described by the asymptotic mass $μ_c$, horizon mass $μ_H$, and profile slope $λ$, it is found that the absorption cross section increases with steeper $λ$, larger $μ_c$ (especially at higher frequencies), or smaller $μ_H$. The differential scattering cross section in this model shows the strongest dependence on the horizon mass $μ_H$. When $μ_H$ exceeds a critical value for a fixed incoming wave frequency $ω$, no partial wave transmits into the black hole, flattening the differential scattering cross section as a function of angle before it increases again with further increase of $μ_H$. Model~II, which considers a truncated accretion region outside some radius $r_0$, contains a potential well in its effective scattering potential. Its absorption cross section decreases in the low-frequency region as the accretion radius $r_0$ decreases, and more importantly, it shows resonance peaks at the quasibound wave frequencies due to resonances induced by the potential well. The differential scattering cross sections show dips around intermediate scattering angles when the parameters (mainly $μ_H$ and $ω$) are such that the resonantly scattered and non-resonant waves interfere destructively around these angles. In both models, absorption exhibits a zero-absorption band as $ω$ approaches $μ_c$ from above, and in both absorption and scattering, the effects of the parameters are found to diminish in the high-frequency limit.

AI.tldr: The paper examines scalar field absorption and scattering by Schwarzschild black holes in scalar-tensor gravity, focusing on two models with different effective mass couplings. Model I's absorption increases with steeper slope λ, larger μ_c, or smaller μ_H, while scattering cross sections depend strongly on μ_H. Model II shows resonance peaks and scattering dips from interference effects. Both models exhibit a zero-absorption band near ω ≈ μ_c and parameter effects fade at high frequencies.
AI.motivation: To understand how scalar-tensor gravity modifies black hole absorption and scattering processes through matter-scalar field coupling, exploring parameter dependencies and resonance phenomena in two distinct effective mass models.
AI.method: Analytical and numerical analysis of scalar field propagation around Schwarzschild black holes under two models. Model I uses a Bondi-type mass model with parameters μ_c, μ_H, and λ to study cross-section variations. Model II incorporates a truncated accretion radius r_0 creating a potential well, analyzed for resonance effects and interference in scattering patterns.
AI.result: Model I shows absorption peaks with specific parameter choices and μ_H-dependent scattering. Model II reveals resonance peaks at quasibound states and angular scattering dips from destructive interference. Both models display a zero-absorption zone near critical frequency and reduced parameter sensitivity at high frequencies.
AI.conclusion: Scalar-tensor gravity's matter-scalar couplings introduce significant deviations in black hole absorption/scattering compared to general relativity, particularly through resonance phenomena and parameter dependencies. These effects are strongest in mid-frequency ranges, offering observational signatures for testing modified gravity theories.

title: Beyond Comoving Volume: Horizon Flux and Matter Creation in Entropic Cosmology
summary: We explore the derivation of the Friedmann equations from a thermodynamic perspective, applying the unified first law of thermodynamics to the apparent horizon of a flat Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker (FLRW) universe. We extend this framework to incorporate gravitationally induced particle creation, treating the region enclosed by the apparent horizon as an open thermodynamic system. A crucial aspect of our analysis is the recognition that the apparent horizon volume is not comoving; this requires a consistent accounting of particle exchange across the moving boundary. We demonstrate that the evolution of the particle number, and explicitly the matter entropy, can be decomposed into two distinct physical contributions: genuine bulk particle production and a net flux induced by the dynamics of the horizon itself. Finally, we derive the Generalized Second Law (GSL) in this setting, showing transparently how the total entropy budget is balanced by horizon thermodynamics, bulk creation, and boundary fluxes.

AI.tldr: Derives Friedmann equations using thermodynamics at apparent horizon, incorporates particle creation, and establishes the Generalized Second Law considering entropy contributions from bulk creation and horizon dynamics.
AI.motivation: To explore the thermodynamic derivation of cosmological equations and understand entropy evolution in expanding universes through particle creation and horizon dynamics.
AI.method: Applied the unified first law of thermodynamics to the FLRW universe's apparent horizon, modeled the system as open with particle creation, and analyzed entropy contributions from bulk production and horizon flux.
AI.result: Showed Friedmann equations emerge from thermodynamic laws, decomposed entropy evolution into two mechanisms, and verified the Generalized Second Law holds by balancing entropies from bulk, horizon, and boundary effects.
AI.conclusion: Thermodynamic approaches provide a foundational framework linking cosmic expansion, particle creation, and entropy, with the GSL ensuring consistency across dynamic horizons.
